snippet: The Christian Church (Disciples of Christ) has elected a woman as president, the first for the 770,000-member Protestant denomination. The Rev. Sharon E. Watkins, senior pastor at Disciples Christian Church in Bartlesville, Okla., was overwhelming...
lead_paragraph: The Christian Church (Disciples of Christ) has elected a woman as president, the first for the 770,000-member Protestant denomination. The Rev. Sharon E. Watkins, senior pastor at Disciples Christian Church in Bartlesville, Okla., was overwhelmingly elected to a six-year term on Tuesday at the denomination's General Assembly in Portland, Ore. ''Today is not about me,'' Ms. Watkins, 51, said. ''Its about all of us joining together and letting God work with us and through us.'' A graduate of Phillips Theological Seminary and Yale Divinity School, Ms. Watkins succeeds the Rev. William Chris Hobgood.

headline.main: National Briefing | Religion: Denomination Elects First Female President

snippet: FROM the recent Supreme Court decision supporting vouchers for religious schools to a lower court objection to the phrase ''one nation under God'' in the pledge of allegiance to wrangling over cloning, stem-cell research, euthanasia and genetic en...
lead_paragraph: FROM the recent Supreme Court decision supporting vouchers for religious schools to a lower court objection to the phrase ''one nation under God'' in the pledge of allegiance to wrangling over cloning, stem-cell research, euthanasia and genetic engineering, religion has been re-entering the public arena in complex and unforeseen ways. The flirtation between the secular and the sacred has traditionally set off alarm bells among American academics, who have often regarded any intrusion of religion into politics as dangerous. In the last century, intellectual giants like John Dewey and Sigmund Freud dismissed religion as infantile and predicted an increasingly secular modern society. In his book ''Human Nature and Conduct'' (Henry Holt, 1922), Dewey said of religion, ''It has been petrified into a slavery of thought and sentiment, as intolerant superiority on the part of the few and an intolerable burden on the part of the many.''
abstract: Growing number of social scientists, philosophers, historians and other scholars are trying to account for energetic re-entry of religion into public sphere, and some are viewing it with much delight as distress; philosopher Michael Novak, Rev Richard John Neuhaus, University of Chicago Prof Jean Bethke Elshtain, Michael Cromartie, vice president of Ethics and Public Policy Center, University of Tennessee Prof Wilfred M McClay, George Mason University Prof Hugh Helco, Center for Inquiry chairman Paul Kurtz and author Wendy Kaminer comment; drawing (M)

headline.main: The Secular Society Gets Religion

snippet: Chatsumarn Kabilsingh gave up her husband, family life and a distinguished career to walk the path of Buddha.    It has led her into a sharp conflict over the lowly and unequal status of women in Buddhist practice in Thailand, reviving a fight fac...
lead_paragraph: Chatsumarn Kabilsingh gave up her husband, family life and a distinguished career to walk the path of Buddha. It has led her into a sharp conflict over the lowly and unequal status of women in Buddhist practice in Thailand, reviving a fight faced by her mother four decades ago.
abstract: Chatsumarn Kabilsingh, 57, female former professor ordained as novice monk in Feb with new name of Dhammananda, faces opposition from Buddhist hierarchy in Thailand that believes only men can enter monkhood; conservative monks and laymen charge she intentionally creates problems that will further erode religion plagued by numerous scandals in recent years; she comments, interview; follows lead of her mother, whose ordination as monk 40 years ago in Taiwan has not been recognized in Thailand (M)

headline.main: Thai Monk Blazes Path For Equality For Women

snippet: FROM the recent Supreme Court decision supporting vouchers for religious schools to a lower court objection to the phrase ''one nation under God'' in the pledge of allegiance to wrangling over cloning, stem-cell research, euthanasia and genetic en...
lead_paragraph: FROM the recent Supreme Court decision supporting vouchers for religious schools to a lower court objection to the phrase ''one nation under God'' in the pledge of allegiance to wrangling over cloning, stem-cell research, euthanasia and genetic engineering, religion has been re-entering the public arena in complex and unforeseen ways. The flirtation between the secular and the sacred has traditionally set off alarm bells among American academics, who have often regarded any intrusion of religion into politics as dangerous. In the last century, intellectual giants like John Dewey and Sigmund Freud dismissed religion as infantile and predicted an increasingly secular modern society. In his book ''Human Nature and Conduct'' (Henry Holt, 1922), Dewey said of religion, ''It has been petrified into a slavery of thought and sentiment, as intolerant superiority on the part of the few and an intolerable burden on the part of the many.''
abstract: Growing number of social scientists, philosophers, historians and other scholars are trying to account for energetic re-entry of religion into public sphere, and some are viewing it with much delight as distress; philosopher Michael Novak, Rev Richard John Neuhaus, University of Chicago Prof Jean Bethke Elshtain, Michael Cromartie, vice president of Ethics and Public Policy Center, University of Tennessee Prof Wilfred M McClay, George Mason University Prof Hugh Helco, Center for Inquiry chairman Paul Kurtz and author Wendy Kaminer comment; drawing (M)

headline.main: The Secular Society Gets Religion

snippet: Chatsumarn Kabilsingh gave up her husband, family life and a distinguished career to walk the path of Buddha.    It has led her into a sharp conflict over the lowly and unequal status of women in Buddhist practice in Thailand, reviving a fight fac...
lead_paragraph: Chatsumarn Kabilsingh gave up her husband, family life and a distinguished career to walk the path of Buddha. It has led her into a sharp conflict over the lowly and unequal status of women in Buddhist practice in Thailand, reviving a fight faced by her mother four decades ago.
abstract: Chatsumarn Kabilsingh, 57, female former professor ordained as novice monk in Feb with new name of Dhammananda, faces opposition from Buddhist hierarchy in Thailand that believes only men can enter monkhood; conservative monks and laymen charge she intentionally creates problems that will further erode religion plagued by numerous scandals in recent years; she comments, interview; follows lead of her mother, whose ordination as monk 40 years ago in Taiwan has not been recognized in Thailand (M)

headline.main: Thai Monk Blazes Path For Equality For Women

snippet: Down in the corner of the clever new Philip Morris ads that seek acceptance for smokers is a clever new logo to signify balance and tolerance -- a yin-yang symbol with smoke curling up from a burning cigarette on one side.   It may seem offensive ...
lead_paragraph: Down in the corner of the clever new Philip Morris ads that seek acceptance for smokers is a clever new logo to signify balance and tolerance -- a yin-yang symbol with smoke curling up from a burning cigarette on one side. It may seem offensive that a cigarette company is using an ancient symbol of complementarity to market tolerance toward smokers. But it makes sense. Yin and yang are symbols of opposites: female and male, light and dark, good and evil, no-smoking and smoking.

snippet: To the Editor:   The answer to the question posed in your editorial about the school-bus controversy in Orange County, ''Who Should Drive Hasidic School Boys?'' (Sept. 15), is not so simple as you suggest. Questions involving apparent conflict bet...
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The answer to the question posed in your editorial about the school-bus controversy in Orange County, ''Who Should Drive Hasidic School Boys?'' (Sept. 15), is not so simple as you suggest. Questions involving apparent conflict between religious belief and law never are. The Hasidim claim that the right to practice their religion is compromised by female drivers transporting male students. Ample precedent supports the legal position that their claim is not automatically overridden by Federal law that prohibits discrimination on account of sex. This is also true even though the female drivers base their claim for certain bus runs on seniority provisions of a collective bargaining agreement. Nor is the fact that the busing is provided from public funds dispositive. But you are correct to say these issues will be decided in the courts.

headline.main: Hasidic Schoolboy Case Is Only Slightly About Sex Discrimination
